Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Saccharomyces diversity and the rapid evolution of hybrid lager-brewing yeast
Award.AbstractNarration:
Brewing yeasts are an attractive living system for studying rapid genetic change because they have adapted to an environment recently created by humans. Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a same warm-adapted species, is traditionally used for wine-making, bread-leavening, and in the bioethanol industry. In contrast, a hybrid of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae strain and a recently discovered species, Saccharomyces eubayanus, are cold-adapted and are used in other applications. The objectives of this study are to determine 1) which traits were contributed to lager yeast by each parent, 2) which genetic changes occurred in the brewing environment, 3) and whether variation in the parental species contributed to lager yeast traits. Hundreds of genome sequences of yeasts isolated from natural and brewing environments will be generated and analyzed to identify candidate differences, which will be tested through genetic manipulation.
Understanding how wild yeast adapt to industrial environments will provide a framework and candidate genes for improving biofuel strains. This project will also help train the next generation of scientists and educators, from high school students and teachers to postdoctoral researchers, including individuals from underrepresented minority backgrounds. In particular, the Yeast Exploration and Analysis Science Team ("Wild YEAST Program") directly involves high school and early-stage undergraduate students in using modern isolation and genetic identification techniques to study natural variation and genetic diversity in Saccharomyces and other yeasts. Visiting high school teachers will develop classroom lab modules that address the Next-Generation Science Standards while engaging students in real biodiversity and genetics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Brewing yeasts are an attractive system for studying rapid genetic change because these fungi have adapted to fermentation environments recently created by humans. In addition to being responsible for the wine, baking, and biofuel industries, traditional ale beers are brewed with the warm-adapted species Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In contrast, lager beers are brewed at colder temperatures with hybrids of S. cerevisiae and the cold-adapted species Saccharomyces eubayanus. Since S. eubayanus was discovered shortly prior to the beginning of the project, little was known about it or what it had contributed to hybrid lager-brewing yeasts. To understand the geographic distribution, physiology, and genetics of the newly discovered species, the project sequenced and analyzed the genomes of more than 200 strains of S. eubayanus and hybrid brewing yeasts. Strains were also manipulated genetically to gain insight into how key traits were encoded in lager yeasts. These experiments showed that aggressive fermentation traits came in large part from S. cerevisiae sugar fermentation genes, while cold tolerance came in large part from the S. eubayanus mitochondrial genome. New strains of S. eubayanus were isolated from the Northern Hemisphere, including the United States of America, and were shown to be among the closest known relatives of hybrid lager yeasts.

            Broader Impacts: Understanding how wild yeasts adapted to industrial beverage fermentation environments provided a framework, set of technologies, and candidate genes for improving biofuel strains. Computational and experimental tools for analyzing and manipulating hybrid yeast genomes were also developed. The project trained a new generation of scientists and educators, from middle school teachers to postdoctoral researchers, including individuals from underrepresented minority backgrounds. In particular, the Yeast Exploration and Analysis Science Team (“Wild YEAST Program”) directly involved dozens of early-stage undergraduate students in genuine, discovery-driven research using modern isolation and genetic identification techniques to study yeast biodiversity. Students discovered the first strains of S. eubayanus from the Northern Hemisphere and several new yeast species. Visiting middle and high school teachers developed classroom lab modules related to their research that implemented Next-Generation Science Standards.
